ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Past month, did you notice and praise your child's good behavior?
Past month, did you reward your child when s/he did something well or practiced a new skill?
Past month, did you avoid struggles with your child by giving clear choices?
Past month, did you warn your child before a change of activity was required?
Past month, did you plan ways to prevent problem behavior?
Past month, did you give reasons for your requests?
Past month, did you use humor when trying to get your child to follow through with everyday tasks or responsibilities?
Past month, did you break tasks into small steps?
Past month, did you prepare your child for a challenging situation?
Past month, did you speak calmly with your child when you were upset with him/her?
Past month, did you stick to your rules and not change your mind?
Past month, did you explain what you wanted your child to do in clear and simple ways?
Past month, did you tell your child what you would like him/her to do when s/he is doing something you don't like?
Past month, did you tell your child how you expected him/her to behave?
Past month, did you set rules on your child's problem behavior that you were willing to enforce?
Past month, did you make sure your child followed the rules that you set?
Last month, how often did you yell or shout at your child?
Last month, how often did you criticize your child?
Last month, how often did you feel that you couldn't handle your child's behavior?
Last month, how often did you feel confident in the way you responded to your child's behavior?
Last month, how often did you use physical discipline with your child?
Last month, how often did you use a time out?
Last month, how often did you take away a privilege?
How often do you make sure that he/she is up on time for school?
How often do you check to see that your child has everything he/she needs for school?
How often do you check to see if he/she has homework?
How often do you eat a meal with him/her?
How often do you check in with your child about his/her day?
How often do you help him/her with school work?
How often do you make sure he/she is in bed on time?
How often do you know what your child does during his/her free time?
How often do you know who your child hangs out with during his/her free time?
How often do you find out if your child does something bad outside the home?
How often do you know how your child is doing in different subjects at school?
How often do you know where your child goes when he/she is out with friends?
How often do you know where your child goes and what your child does after school?
How often do you know what your child is doing when you are away from home?
How often do you have a pretty good idea about your child's plans for the coming day?
How often do you have a pretty good idea about your child's interests and activities?

Think about parenting your child in the past month. Were you able to - Notice and praise your child's good behavior (such as, ''Good job putting away your toys.'') - Was this a problem for you?
Think about parenting your child in the past month. Were you able to - Teach your child new skills (such as tying their shoes)?
Notes: 1 = Not at all; 4 = Sometimes; 7 = Most of the time; -9 = Missing
